persona.name: Ruby Mae Thornton

occupation.title: Unemployed / occasional day laborer
occupation.description: Currently unemployed with sporadic informal work. Past jobs include short stints as a seasonal factory packer, janitorial/cleaning work at a motel, occasional day labor (~landscaping, demolition) paid in cash, and several months doing in-home caregiving that ended badly. Doesn't trust formal employment systems (views them as exploitative) but will take cash jobs when necessary. Responsibilities when working included basic manual labor: sweeping, lifting boxes, cleaning bathrooms, shoveling, unloading trucks. Has limited formal training; strengths are reliability in physical, repetitive tasks for short bursts, and the ability to improvise with limited tools. Barriers now include unstable mental health, patchy references, no reliable transportation, and resentment toward job centers and social services which she feels 'never helped.'

persona.residence: Coal Hollow, West Virginia (small former mining town)
persona.education: Formal education ended after primary school (completed 6th grade). Attended a handful of community adult-education nights once, tried a GED booklet for a few weeks but gave up. Literate but has patchy spelling and grammar; reads newspapers and comments sections more than books. Learned practical skills on the job and from family rather than in classrooms.
long_term_goals: To have enough consistent money to stop worrying about whether next week the lights will be cut off.
To not have to rely on food banks or church handouts every month.
To avoid getting sicker or more broken — keep moving and intact, even if nothing improves.
To not be made to feel ashamed by relatives or officials again.
To keep her tiny trailer together so she doesn't end up on the street.
To be left alone and not called by agencies she distrusts.
A vague hope that one day the noise in her head will quiet; not sure how, but she clings to that hope.
To preserve a small legacy for a niece — a faded photo, a thrift-store china cup, something her family might keep.
persona.style: Speaks with a dry, world-weary Southern Appalachian cadence; words often soft, voice low and flat. Frequent long sighs between sentences. Uses sarcastic, cutting humor aimed to deflate others rather than connect. Often monosyllabic replies or clipped sentences. Prefers blunt, plain language punctuated by bitter little asides. Avoids eye contact; tends to clasp hands or fiddle with a cigarette/pen; posture is slightly hunched. Clothes: worn jeans, thrift-store sweaters, mismatched shoes; favors dark, utilitarian outerwear. Smells faintly of tobacco and old coffee. When upset, voice drops to near-whisper and she withdraws. When angry, she smiles thinly and delivers undermining, undermining sarcasm rather than overt yelling. Uses local idioms and curse words sparingly but effectively to puncture what she sees as nonsense.

traits: Deeply pessimistic: habitually expects the worst and interprets neutral events as negative.
Chronic hopelessness: believes problems are unlikely to improve, which suppresses motivation.
Highly critical: uses sarcasm to belittle others' efforts without offering help.
Bitter and resentful: focuses on perceived slights and systemic unfairness.
Introverted and guarded: avoids new social situations; trusts very few people.
Brooding and ruminative: replays past hurts and imagined failures for long periods.
Passive-aggressive: avoids direct confrontation but expresses disdain through silence and backhanded remarks.
Practical in small ways: can make do with minimal resources and improvise solutions.
Skeptical of institutions: assumes agencies and officials are indifferent or dishonest.
Low-energy but tenacious: lacks enthusiasm yet can persist in routine, gritty survival tasks.
Emotionally reactive: small setbacks can trigger disproportionate distress and catastrophizing.
A streak of dark humor: laughs at bleak things to cope, often at others' discomfort.

big_five.openness: Low (25/100). Conservative mentally, not drawn to novelty; prefers familiar routines.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low to moderate (30/100). Can be responsible about immediate survival tasks but disorganized long-term.
big_five.extraversion: Very low (10/100). Drained by people, prefers solitude and small trusted circle.
big_five.agreeableness: Low (20/100). Distrustful, easily irritated, often unsupportive or cutting.
big_five.neuroticism: Very high (95/100). Frequently anxious, sad, irritable, and emotionally unstable under stress.

interests: Reading local news headlines and the opinion/comment sections, especially stories about corruption or welfare fraud.
Watching bleak crime dramas and documentaries (prefers stories where systems fail people).
Listening to old country and blues records on a battered portable radio.
Collecting plastic grocery loyalty cards and coupons, sifting for anything useful.
Tinkering with small repairs around the trailer: patching a roof seam, fixing a leaky faucet with jury-rigged parts.
Scrolling long threads of customer complaints and writing long, scathing reviews.
Keeping a tiny vegetable pot with herbs on the trailer step (rosemary survived seven winters).
Observing neighbors from the porch rather than interacting directly.
Attending (rarely) a free community meal but sitting apart.
Watching weather warnings and taking them seriously as threats to stability.
likes: Strong black coffee from a thermos — bitter, no sugar.
Cheap, greasy breakfast sandwiches that feel like a small treat.
The tactile feel of thick paperbacks bought at secondhand stores.
Used bookstores and thrift stores (browses for practical items, rarely buys).
Smoking menthol cigarettes (or whatever is cheapest) — a habitual hand-to-mouth comfort.
Dark, overcast afternoons that match mood and make leaving the house optional.
Quiet corners of laundromats where she can sit with headphones and judge the world.
Long, scathing reviews as a creative outlet — precise, vindictive prose gives satisfaction.
Minimal social obligation: prefers people to talk to her only if absolutely necessary.
Functional clothing with pockets and stains that hide wear.
dislikes: Large social gatherings and community events framed as 'helpful' but full of cheer.
Anyone who tells her to 'cheer up' or 'just get out there' — sees it as naive cruelty.
Charity with strings attached or patronizing tones from volunteers.
Local bureaucrats who require complex forms and give vague promises.
Neighbors who chat loudly on porches early in the morning.
Self-improvement programs that promise quick fixes.
Chain grocery stores that jack up prices and hide waste.
Programs that 'help' but require too much documentation or travel.
Gentrification talk — resents outsiders who don't understand daily scarcity.
consumer_behavior: Writes long, scathing negative reviews for businesses and services she feels wronged by.
Prefers cash transactions; avoids credit and accounts that create obligations.
Shops at the cheapest grocery or dollar stores and hoards discounts.
Seldom returns items; if disappointed, posts a public complaint instead.
Avoids loyalty programs that require tracking—except the ones that give immediate coupons.

beliefs: Most systems (welfare, health, employment) are designed to make people fail or feel smaller.
People in power are indifferent or actively exploit the poor.
Luck and accident explain more of life than hard work does in the modern economy.
Helping someone with a handout usually doesn't change their life; it creates dependency — and it's often a con.
Community platitudes about 'pulling yourself up' ignore structural problems.
Neighborhoods labeled 'revitalized' mean more expensive rents and fewer options for people like her.
Charities often provide conditional dignity rather than real help.
Government promises are rhetorical; rarely do they translate to consistent support.
Most people are performative about compassion; few actually help in meaningful ways.
Personal suffering is usually private and invisible — public concern evaporates quickly.
The workplace is a place to be used until you're spent; loyalty is hand-to-mouth.
People with education dismiss the poor as lazy without understanding context.
Medical professionals often write people off if they don't have insurance or resources.
Mental health services are expensive, slow, and full of paperwork; they rarely help in the ways people expect.
Religion is complicated: church can be both solace and a source of judgement.
Family ties are fragile; people will prioritize their own survival over solidarity.
Small kindnesses matter but are unreliable; better to expect none.
Most 'success stories' are exceptions, not templates to emulate.
Media stories amplify the worst parts of life and make people feel invisible unless dramatic.
Complaints are useful — calling attention publicly is sometimes the only leverage poorer people have.
Being self-sufficient is overrated when systems are stacked against you, but it's also the only practical option sometimes.
Officials give lip service to 'help' but create barriers that feel intentional.
One mistake can cascade into permanent damage when you have no cushion.
Trust is a commodity she has spent and cannot replenish easily.
Social services are often punitive, penalizing people for paperwork errors rather than helping.
People who offer unsolicited optimism are usually clueless or judgemental.
Learning skills helps, but without stability skills are less useful.
Hope without tangible changes is a slow form of cruelty.
Expressing vulnerability is risky; it's often met with dismissal or exploitation.
Being invisible is both protective and isolating—keeps you safe but also keeps you poor.
skills: Practical household repairs: patching roofs with tar, sealing leaks, basic plumbing fixes using improvised parts.
Manual labor aptitude: lifting, packing, shoveling, and repetitive cleaning tasks.
Basic vehicle maintenance: changing a tire, replacing a battery, checking oil and belts.
Cooking to stretch resources: turning limited staples into hearty, inexpensive meals (stews, casseroles, one-pot dinners).
Couponing and finding local discounted food programs; knows which stores have lowest-priced staples.
Writing long, detailed complaint letters and online reviews; good at crafting persuasive, scathing narratives.
Bartering and negotiating cash deals with local laborers.
Neighborhood-level observation: reads people and patterns in small communities; memory for who owes who favors.
Survival planning for short-term crises: what to secure first when a storm is coming.
Basic first aid: cleaning wounds, dressing simple injuries, splinting improvised braces.
Resourcefulness with limited tools and materials (repurposes items rather than throwing out).
Managing household budget on a shoestring: prioritizes bills and barters to cover essentials.
Low-bandwidth internet skills: finds forms, complaint portals, and free services online despite limited tech fluency.
Emotional boundary setting: withdraws to avoid being drained, which is a coping skill albeit isolating.

general: Withdrawal from social interaction and long stretches of solitude.
Ruminates on slights and imagined slights for hours, often replaying conversations.
Uses sarcasm to undercut others' attempts at friendliness.
Writes public complaints and long negative reviews as a regular pastime.
Avoids asking for help until desperate; when she does, asks in blunt terms and expects to be dismissed.
Smokes frequently, especially when stressed; hand-to-mouth motion is calming.
Hoards small useful items (duct tape, canned goods, spare socks) and takes comfort in having backups.
Chooses avoidance over confrontation but keeps a running internal indictment of people who 'did her wrong.'
Sleeps irregularly — long naps some days, restless nights other times.
Prefers errands early morning or late evening to avoid people.

morning: Wakes between 6:30–8:30 AM depending on how worried she was overnight.
Makes a black coffee in a dented percolator, sips standing by the trailer window.
Smokes and scans local news on her cheap smartphone, making mental notes of injustices.
Checks the mailbox and the community bulletin board for notices or coupons.
If expecting a job, lazes and waits; if none, sits on the porch and watches neighbors' cars.
workday: If a cash job exists, packs a simple sandwich and heads out early; returns exhausted and resentful.
Spends long stretches at home doing small cleaning, fixing, and organizing to a messy standard.
Writes one or two long, bitter reviews or complaint letters online instead of applying to structured jobs.
Occasionally volunteers at a church food pantry to get a meal and observe people.
Calls a sister or cousin infrequently and keeps the conversation guarded and negative.
evening: Eats a simple meal — canned soup or beans with stale bread.
Listens to the radio or an old playlist; darker songs are preferred.
Smokes, reads forums, and composes sharp replies to perceived hypocrisy online.
Falls asleep watching low-rez TV police dramas or news; often wakes overnight worrying.
Sometimes writes long entries in a small notebook — not a journal in the therapeutic sense, more a ledger of grievances.
weekend: Weekends don't feel different; sometimes goes to town to collect free food from church drives.
Avoids family gatherings even when invited, citing reasons; attends only if pressured and then sits silent.
Tends to the small vegetable pot and looks after neighbors' pets for cash or favors occasionally.
Walks around the block late at night to clear her head, often imagining worst-case scenarios.

mental_health: Chronic major depressive symptoms: persistent low mood, loss of interest, low energy, hopelessness.
High anxiety and frequent catastrophizing in response to small setbacks.
Likely dysthymia or long-term depressive disorder rooted in economic and social stressors.
Avoids formal therapy due to distrust and cost; had one short counseling session years ago that she abandoned.
Frequent rumination and negative self-talk; expresses beliefs that improvement is unlikely.
physical_health: Chronic back pain from years of manual labor; manages with over-the-counter painkillers and rest.
Smoker; signs of chronic bronchitic cough and reduced exercise tolerance.
Poor dental health: missing molars, sensitive gums, sporadic dental visits only in crisis.
Irregular sleep patterns: insomnia some nights, hypersomnolence other days.
Underweight to normal weight depending on food access; dietary insufficiencies from inconsistent meals.
Untreated or poorly managed hypertension suspected (rare doctor visits, occasional dizzy spells).
Low energy and stamina; easily exhausted by work or travel.
Limited preventive care — rarely sees a primary care provider unless forced by an emergency.
substance_use: Occasional heavy drinking when stressed (episodic binge drinking), but not daily dependence-level drinking documented.
Avoids prescription medications when they require long-term monitoring due to mistrust of doctors and pharmacies.

relationships.name: Evelyn Thornton
relationships.description: Contact is strained. Evelyn is stoic, religious, and often critical. They exchange curt phone calls. Evelyn occasionally leaves canned goods on the porch but also lectures Ruby about 'attitude' and 'pride.' There is love under the surface but a lot of mutual resentment.

relationships.name: Lena Carter
relationships.description: Lena lives two towns over and sometimes sends small amounts of money or groceries. Relationship is transactional: Lena helps when pressed but is frustrated by Ruby's resistance to structured help. They argue about lifestyle choices and expectations.

relationships.name: Tommy 'Buck' Harris
relationships.description: On-and-off, sometimes abusive emotionally. Left years ago; occasionally shows up drunk and is told off from the porch. Ruby is wary and keeps a strict boundary now.

relationships.name: June Parker
relationships.description: Older woman who brings casseroles sometimes and checks incidents. Ruby tolerates June — can be sarcastic with her but appreciates the occasional kindness.

relationships.name: Caseworker (first name unknown)
relationships.description: Interacts rarely and bureaucratically. Ruby distrusts them, finds appointments exhausting and unhelpful but keeps a file of communications out of over-caution.

relationships.name: Niece (Maya)
relationships.description: Ruby adores Maya in a guarded way. Buys small treats when she can, leaves old books and clothes. Wants to protect the child from the family's dysfunction and is quietly proud when Maya succeeds in school.

relationships.name: Online acquaintances
relationships.description: Ruby has a few recurring pen-pals and commenters in local forums; exchanges scathing takes and sometimes coordinated complaints about local businesses.

other_facts: Born and raised in the same county; family history tied to mining and seasonal work.
First job at 13 folding flyers and helping at a gas station; left school to help the family after a parent fell ill.
Remembered a single teacher who called her 'lost cause' in front of class — still repeats that line aloud in private.
Cared for an ailing father in her twenties which interrupted steady work; resentment built toward systems that didn't help.
Spent a year living transiently with an ex-partner in a rundown camper — still has a scar on her forearm from an incident then.
Has a faded wedding band in a drawer from a brief marriage that ended in separation and paperwork left unfinished.
Once saved a neighbor's child from a backyard fire; the family still sends a Christmas card; Ruby says she 'doesn't deserve the thank-you.'
Keeps a shoebox of letters and a few photos; opening it is rare and emotionally risky.
Learned to read repair manuals and appliance labels from scraps and the library when she could make time.
Refuses to throw out an old porcelain teacup that belonged to her grandmother despite it being cracked.
Has a persistent distrust of charity drives after being judged at one once for smelling like smoke.
Knows where to get free bread at the church on Thursdays and goes when the gas tank is nearly empty.
Once worked a month of overtime at a factory and used the pay to buy a used refrigerator — still proud of that purchase.
Hates the phrase 'just pull yourself up by your bootstraps' and will often respond with a sarcastic quip when she hears it.
Has a tiny scar on the eyebrow from falling off a porch as a child — remembers the laughter of others more than the pain.
Owns a dog years ago named 'Patch' who was rehomed when she moved into a smaller trailer; still asks about the dog at neighbors' houses.
Learned to cook from an elderly aunt; recipes are practical and thrifty — stews, bones for broth, frying potatoes.
Keeps an old radio that still works on AM and listens for local call-ins and church programs occasionally out of habit.
Was once expelled from a job for arguing with a supervisor who refused to fix dangerous equipment.
Has a pattern of taking one step forward, two steps back in employment due to health or an interpersonal conflict.
Keeps a small stack of receipts and a handwritten ledger to track when bills were paid; obsessive about a few bills and neglectful of others.
Has a neighbor's sun-faded rocking chair that she claims was the only real gift she received in years.
Collects small compliments in a jar mentally and refuses to show them to anyone — sees them as liabilities.
Has never had a passport and has no interest in travel beyond the occasional bus trip to a larger town.
Knows the shortest route to the public assistance office and judges its parking from memory.
Kept a prayer candle for three months during an attempt at church attendance; stopped when she felt judged by the congregation.
Once got into a fistfight in a bar over a job contract gone wrong — the memory is complicated and she alternates between shame and pride.
Has a damaged molar she's convinced no dentist can fix right; delays treatment due to cost despite pain.
Knows the names and peccadillos of many local officials and uses that knowledge when writing complaints.
Has a long-standing, low-level insomnia pattern that peaks before major bills are due.
Was once briefly involved with a volunteer-run cooperative garden; left after a disagreement over distribution fairness.
Keeps a small stack of postcards from an aunt in another state; reads them when feeling particularly alone.
Believes her voice online has more power than it does in person; uses forums to vent because face-to-face confrontation feels too risky.
Has a superstition about not leaving the front light off during storms; keeps a tiny battery lantern by the door.
Still remembers the first paycheck she ever earned and hid half of it in a jar under the mattress; that habit to stash cash persists.
Has seen multiple friends and acquaintances move away and never return; interprets moves as escapes she was denied.
Once tried a community college welding course but dropped out due to transportation barriers and a family emergency.
Maintains a thin, private archive of clippings about local corruption and business closures.
Has a scarred, yellowed birth certificate copy she carries for appointments instead of the original; distrusts mailed documents.
Sings off-key in the kitchen to keep from thinking about debt.
Still uses an old phrase her grandmother used: 'Keep your shoes on, 'til you're sure the road's free.' She interprets it as a survival motto.
Feels guilty about small comforts she indulges in (a cinnamon roll, a soda), then rationalizes them as necessary for morale.
Believes in small acts of resistance — exposing poor service publicly, refusing to be gaslighted — as a way to keep dignity.
